   Assessment and Plan
   61yo male now Day +9 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred
   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and
   meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   yesterday highly suggestive of ARDS given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also
   includes post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome as in
   correct time frame per Heme-Onc; received
   1. Altered Mental Status
   Etiology of his altered mental status is likely multifactorial related
   to his gram negative rod bacteremia and hypercarbia related to
   parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia. Encephalitis or
   meningitis are also possible. Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]
   and had only 1 WBCs, although this is difficult to interpret in the
   setting of neutropenia. His glucose and total protein were normal,
   which is somewhat reassuring. Additional infection is also possible,
   although cultures remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia
   has been relatively chronic during this admission and is likely not a
   large contributor to his altered mental status.
   - will start treatmement for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   desensitization protocol (see below)
   - will start noninvasive ventilation for increased ventilation to
   improve his hypercarbia with intubation as needed
   - follow-up CSF Cultures
   - follow-up CSF studies - Toxoplasma gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and
   Coccidiodes
   - avoid further psychotropic medications
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   2. E. coli Bacteremia and UTI
   Patient had ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**], although subsequent urine
   cultures were negative after treatment with aztreonam. Surprisingly
   then his blood cultures returned with ESBL bacteremia on [**2165-3-15**],
   despite clearing of his urinary tract infection. He has been on
   aztreonam and gentamicin for treatment of this, although meropenem
   would be preferred in this patient due to inferiority of gentamicin in
   neutropenic patients. Patient unfortunately has anaphylaxis reaction to
   penicillins in the past and will need meropenem desensitiziation
   protocol for this.
   - discontinue gentamicin
   - continue vancomycin for broad gram positive coverage in this patient
   with febrile neutropenia, will follow-up with BMT regarding peeling
   this back given no gram positive infection to date and cultures NGTD
   - will follow-up with BMT team regarding need for micafungin
   - allergy consultation
   - start meropenem desensitization protocol once respiratory status is
   improved
   - will need tunneled catheter removed by interventional radiology once
   patient is stable from a respiratory standpoint and has received first
   dose of meropenem
   - daily blood cultures
   - appreciate ID input
   3. Hypoxia and Hypercarbia
   Patient is both hypoxic and hypercarbic, likely due to parainfluenza
   infection and obstructive sleep apnea.
   - will try noninvasive ventilation to improve oxygenation and
   ventilation; if no improvement will need to intubate
   4. Myeloma
   Patient is now day + 9 for SCT for multiple myeloma.
   - appreciate BMT recs
   - continue acyclovir, clotrimazole, and bactrim prophylaxis
   - continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   - continue immunosuppression with cyclosporine and mycophenolate
   mofetil
   5. Hyponatremia
   Etiology is most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia.
   - continue to monitor daily sodium
   - continue free water restriction
   - continue salt tabs
   6. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
   Patient with difficult to control blood glucose in the setting of
   infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   - appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   - continue insulin sliding scale with lantus
   7. Hypertension
   Patient has a history of hypertension in the past requiring Metoprolol
   Succinate 50mg PO bid and amlodipine 2.5mg PO daily. Currently
   normotensive
   - hold Toprol XL and amlodipine in the setting of gram negative rod
   bacteremia and will restart if BP increases
   8. Depression
   Patient has a history of major depression with significant medication
   requirements.
   - appreciate psychiatry input
   - continue duloxetine and lorazepam PO/IV prn
   9. Glaucoma
   Stable
   - continue timolol eye drops
   10. Hyperlipidemia
   Stable
   - hold atorvastatin in the acute setting
   11. Peripheral Neuropathy and Pain
   Stable
   - continue gapabentin, oxycontin, and oxycodone prn
   12. GERD
   Stable
   - continue PPI
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO for now pending improvement in respiratory status
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale

   Tunneled (Hickman) Line - [**2165-3-17**] 12:15 PM

   Disposition: ICU
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who is on day 9 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.

Respiratory distress: The patient has quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates yesterday, highly suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The differential diagnosis also includes post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome, as suggested by the hematology-oncology team. 

Altered mental status: The etiology of the altered mental status is likely multifactorial, including gram-negative rod bacteremia and hypercarbia related to parainfluenza infection, further worsened by hyponatremia. Encephalitis or meningitis are also possible, although lumbar puncture results showed only 1 WBC, which may not be reliable due to neutropenia. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures remain negative for additional infection. 

Treatment plan:
- Start treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem desensitization protocol.
- Start noninvasive ventilation to improve oxygenation and ventilation, and intubation as needed.
- Follow-up CSF cultures and studies, including Toxoplasma gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and Coccidioid

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who is now on day 9 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient has several medical complications including altered mental status, hypoxia, hypercarbia, E. coli bacteremia and UTI, hyponatremia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy and pain, GERD, and myeloma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Altered Mental Status: The etiology of the altered mental status is likely multifactorial, including gram-negative rod bacteremia, hypercarbia related to parainfluenza infection, and hyponatremia.
2. Hypoxia and Hypercarbia: The patient is both hypoxic and hypercarbic, likely due to parainfluenza infection and obstructive sleep apnea.
3. E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: The patient has an ongoing ESBL E. coli bacteremia despite previous treatment for a urinary tract infection.
4. Hyponatremia: The etiology is most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or pneumonia.
5. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's blood glucose is difficult

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male on day +9 of allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma, admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. He has a history of multiple medical conditions including type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy and pain, GERD, and allergies to penicillins.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory distress with evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), altered mental status likely due to a combination of factors such as gram-negative rod bacteremia, hypercarbia related to parainfluenza infection, and hyponatremia. He also has E. coli bacteremia and urinary tract infection (UTI) with ESBL-producing strain, oliguric renal failure, and myeloma.

The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a goal tidal volume of 4 mL/kg ideal body weight according to ARDS protocol. He is being treated with vancomycin, meropenem, and micafungin, and will undergo bronchoscopy with lavage to rule out various infectious etiologies. Additional cultures are pending.

Other ongoing concerns include the need for a renal consult due to oliguric renal failure, possible line-related infection, and the potential

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current medical conditions and potential complications are as follows:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), likely secondary to severe sepsis with GNR bacteremia. There are bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and the patient's oxygenation is compromised. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume ventilation. The plan includes weaning the FiO2 to 0.5, utilizing balloon monitoring if FiO2 cannot be weaned, and obtaining sputum samples for viral and bacterial pathogens.

2. Sepsis: The patient has significant bacteremia and sepsis, likely due to indwelling catheters. Antibiotic choices have been limited by the patient's anaphylactic reaction to penicillin in the past. The patient has tolerated desensitization to meropenem, and vancomycin/meropenem therapy is being continued. Other antibiotics such as mycophenfungin are also being used. All central venous lines should be removed and replaced with tunneled lines for ongoing sepsis management. 

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is likely experiencing pre-renal acute renal failure, possibly due to sepsis and ATN. Close monitoring of urine output is essential, and if oliguria occurs, continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) may be necessary.

4. Post-transplant complications: The patient

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male who is currently on day +9 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.

The patient's respiratory distress is attributed to ARDS, which is likely secondary to sepsis and known parainfluenza pneumonia. Other possible causes include post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome. The patient has bilateral patchy infiltrates on imaging, consistent with ARDS. He is being mechanically ventilated according to ARDSnet protocol with a goal Vt of 4 mL/kg IBW.

The patient also has altered mental status, which is likely multifactorial and related to infection and hypercarbia. A lumbar puncture was performed, showing normal glucose and total protein levels, reassuring against additional infection. Further studies are planned to rule out other potential infections.

The patient has an ongoing E. coli bacteremia and urinary tract infection (UTI) despite previous treatment with aztreonam and gentamicin. He has been desensitized to meropenem, which is now being used for treatment.

Renal failure is present, likely due to hypotension during intubation, increased lactate, volume depletion, supratherapeutic cyclosporine levels, gentamic

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male admitted with sepsis and respiratory failure, diagnosed with ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome). He has para-influenza 3 seen on BAL specimen, indicating a viral infection. The patient has blood alveolar secretions but without progressively bloody return, suggesting a pattern of diffuse alveolar damage and leak of RBC's into the alveolar space.

1) ARDS/Respiratory Failure: The patient's ARDS has been managed with optimization of PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) and ventilatory support using lung-protective strategies. CXR (chest X-ray) shows minimal change day to day, with peak inspiratory pressures ranging from 24, which are reasonable and well tolerated. The plan is to up-titrate PEEP to 12, continue with low Vt (tidal volume) strategy, and allow for permissive hypercapnia. FIO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen) weaning to 0.4 will be trialed.

2) RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF): The patient's renal function is impaired due to factors such as hypotension, medication effects, contrast effects, and sepsis. He is currently anuric (producing little to no urine). CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) may be required for volume removal if oxygen

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. He underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma and is now on day +9. The patient's respiratory status has been deteriorating, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). There is also concern for post-transplant reaction, engraftment syndrome, or bacterial pneumonia. The patient tested positive for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen in the bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) sample.

The patient's altered mental status is likely multifactorial, related to infection and hypercarbia secondary to parainfluenza pneumonia. Lumbar puncture results showed normal glucose and total protein levels, reassuring against additional infection. The patient has a history of ESBL E. coli bacteremia and urinary tract infection (UTI), which is currently being treated with meropenem. He also has acute renal failure (ARF), possibly related to hypotension during intubation, increased lactate, volume depletion, supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Acyclovir-related ARF is considered the top differential. The patient's anemia is being managed with packed red blood cells (

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who is currently on day +12 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient's respiratory status has been worsening, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of ARDS. The patient is mechanically ventilated, and the goal is to wean PEEP as tolerated while providing adequate oxygenation.

The patient's altered mental status is likely multifactorial, related to infection and hypercarbia secondary to parainfluenza pneumonia. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures remain negative. Hyponatremia has been relatively chronic during this admission and is not thought to be a significant contributor to the altered mental status.

The patient has a history of E. coli bacteremia and urinary tract infection, which has been treated with aztreonam, gentamicin, and now meropenem. Renal failure is present, likely due to hypotension during intubation, increased lactate, volume depletion, supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment shows numerous crystals, suggesting acyclovir-related acute renal failure.

Other issues include anemia, myeloma, hyponatremia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression,

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, diabetes mellitus type II, and renal failure, who was admitted with sepsis, ARDS, and some component of alveolar hemorrhage but not evidence of active pulmonary capillaritis. He has been tolerating low VT ventilation and PEEP titration well.

The potential medical complications that can arise include respiratory failure/ARDS, sepsis, and acute renal failure. The patient's mental status and volume overload are the main barriers to extubation. The sepsis is being treated with antibiotics and antifungal medication. Acute renal failure is multifactorial, and renal input is appreciated. The patient's nutrition is being managed through total parenteral nutrition (TF), and glycemic control is being maintained with regular insulin sliding scale.

It is important to monitor the patient closely for any changes in respiratory status, as well as for improvement in urine output and renal function. Regular assessment of mental status is also crucial for evaluating readiness to wean sedation and attempt spontaneous breathing trials (PSV).

   transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status,

   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates

   -Continue to wean PEEP and try daily pressure support trials.

   -improvement in respiratory status will largely depend upon improving

   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.

   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively

   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem

   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to

   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He is currently on day +13 of the SCT and was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient has several medical complications, including respiratory distress with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of ARDS, altered mental status likely multifactorial, E. coli bacteremia and urinary tract infection, acute renal failure possibly due to acyclovir, anemia, myeloma, hyponatremia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, GERD, and others.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a high risk of developing further complications related to his lung condition.
2. Infection: The patient has an ongoing E. coli bacteremia and urinary tract infection, which can lead to sepsis and worsen his overall condition.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and there is a risk of further deterioration, potentially requiring renal replacement therapy.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is altered, making it difficult to assess his pain

The patient has shown significant improvement in respiratory failure and is now able to tolerate weaning of PEEP and move to PSV support. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure needs to be controlled, and there is ongoing use of atenolol for this purpose.

5. Multiple Myeloma: This is an underlying condition that may contribute to the patient's overall health status and susceptibility to infections or other complications.

6. Volume Overload: The patient's fluid balance indicates a positive total input-output balance, suggesting volume overload. This needs to be managed appropriately.

7. Nutritional Status: The patient is receiving a renal diet, which is important for managing his renal failure.

   61 yo man now Day +14 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma
   transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status,
   hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   were highly suggestive of ARDS in setting of sepsis and known
   parainfluenza pneumonia given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also includes volume
   overload from renal failure, post-transplant reaction and engraftment
   syndrome as in correct time frame and given increased WBC per Heme-Onc.
   BAL viral screen positive for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen,
   negative for PCP.
   [**Name10 (NameIs) 7416**] vent (goal Vt 4mg/kg IBW per ARDS protocol)
   -continue to wean PEEP and try daily pressure support trials;
   spontaneous breathing trial today
   -continue meropenem and vancomycin
   -continue micafungin
   -improvement in respiratory status will largely depend upon improving
   renal function, as well as tx of pneumonia as above
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.
   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret
   in the setting of neutropenia but nl glucose and total protein
   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   -CSF studies negative to date. Continue to follow up other culture
   data.
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -will leave lines in for now, pending surveillance cultures
   -daily blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # ARF: Oliguric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top
   of the differential.
   -continue CVVH per renal team
   -dose all meds for GFR <10
   # Anemia: hematocrit 20 decreased from 25 on [**2165-3-20**].
   -guiaic all stools
   -transfuse for <21
   # Myeloma: Patient is now day +14 of SCT for multiple myeloma.
   -Dose cyclosporine per level; goal around 200.
   -f/u BMT recs
   -holding acyclovir d/t probable acyclovir-related acute renal failure
   -nystatin for thrush prophylaxis
   -continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   -continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil;
   -avoiding steroids if possible d/t viral pneumonia
   # Hyponatremia: Most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia. Currently stable.
   -continue to monitor daily sodium
   -continue free water restriction
   -CVVH as above
   # Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Difficult to control blood glucose in the
   setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   -appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   -continue humalog sliding scale with Lantus,
 dose as patient is NPO
   # Hypertension: Patient has a history of hypertension in the past
   requiring metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 **] and amlodipine 2.5 qday. [**Month (only) 51**] be related to
   decreasing sedation and agitation.  Unable to assess if patient in
   pain.
   -continue metoprolol and amlodipine
   -consider restarted nitro gtt if hypertensive
   # Depression: Patient has a history of major depression with
   significant medication requirements.
   -appreciate psychiatry input
   -hold duloxetine for now
   # Glaucoma
   -continue timolol eye drops
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -holding atorvastatin in acute setting
   # Peripheral Neuropathy and Pain

   -continue lansoprazole

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old man who is currently on day 14 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma. He was admitted to the ICU for altered mental status, hypoxia, and desensitization for meropenem due to an ESBL E. coli bacteremia. 

The patient's respiratory distress has worsened, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). His PaO2:FiO2 ratio is less than 200. The BAL viral screen was positive for parainfluenza type 3, while other cultures remain negative. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, with plans to wean PEEP and try daily pressure support trials. 

The patient's altered mental status is likely multifactorial, related to infection and hypercarbia from parainfluenza pneumonia. Lumbar puncture results showed normal glucose and total protein levels. The patient's renal function is oliguric and likely multifactorial, possibly due to hypotension, increased lactate, volume depletion, supratherapeutic cyclosporine levels, gentamicin, recent contrast load, and acyclovir. CVVH is being continued, and all medications are being dosed for a GFR of less than 10.

The patient's anemia is significant, with a hematocrit of 20. He is being transfused for less than 21. His myeloma treatment includes cyclosporine dosing per level, with a goal around 200. 

Other medical conditions include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyponatremia, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, GERD, and anemia. 

The patient's medications include meropenem for E. coli bacteremia, vancomycin, micafungin, CVVH, and other immunosuppressive drugs. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure due to ARDS.
2. Infection-related complications, including line infections and sinus infection.
3. Acyclovir-related acute renal failure.
4. Volume overload from renal failure.
5. Post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome.
6. Continued bacteremia and urinary tract infection from ESBL E. coli.
7. Poor glycemic control in the setting of infection and underlying diabetes mellitus.
8. Hypertension management.
9. Further evaluation and management of altered mental status.
10. Monitoring and management of anemia.
11. Monitoring and management of hyperlipidemia.
12. Long-term management of myeloma and immunosuppression.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with respiratory distress and has undergone meropenem desensitization. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.8°C (101.8°F), heart rate of 114 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 94/54 mmHg to 173/78 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is intubated and sedated, with clear lungs anteriorly but there are concerns about a potential line infection, sinus infection, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 

The patient has received various medications including fentanyl, midazolam, calcium gluconate (CRRT), nitroglycerin, and other ICU medications. The patient's weight is currently 145 kg, with a height of 72 inches. 

Fluid balance shows an input of 2,718 mL, including 445 mL through PO and 1,943 mL through IVF. Output includes 1,003 mL of urine, 780 mL of NG drainage, and 30 mL of stool drainage. The respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator, set Vt of 500 mL, PS of 8 cmH2O, RR set at 14, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and an RSBI of 91. 

Physical examination reveals obesity, intubation, and sedation, with a right-sided portacath and left-sided tunneled catheter over an erythematous patch, possibly an old XRT site. The patient is tachycardic with frequent premature atrial contractions (PACs), and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops are heard. The lungs are clear anteriorly, and the abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended with no bowel sounds. There is 1+ pitting edema on the dorsum of the feet and bilateral upper extremity edema that is non-pitting. 

Laboratory results show a WBC count of 6.8 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.5 g/dL, sodium of 120 mg/dL, potassium of 5.1 mEq/L, chloride of 100 mEq/L, bicarbonate of 22.6%, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 68 mg/dL, creatinine of 7.0 mg/dL, glucose of 170 mg/dL, and platelet count of 68 K/uL. Other lab values include prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT), as well as elevated liver enzymes. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory distress, line infection, sinus infection, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret

   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem

   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -will leave lines in for now, pending surveillance cultures
   -daily blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # ARF: Oliguric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old man who is currently on day 14 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma. He was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient's respiratory status has worsened, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of ARDS. His mental status is likely multifactorial, possibly due to infection, hypercarbia related to parainfluenza pneumonia, and hyponatremia. The patient also has anemia, myeloma, hyponatremia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, GERD, and other medical conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is deteriorating, with bilateral patchy infiltrates indicating ARDS. There is a concern for volume overload from renal failure, post-transplant reaction, and engraftment syndrome. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and efforts are being made to wean PEEP and perform spontaneous breathing trials.

2. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is likely due to a combination of factors, including infection, hypercarbia from parainfluenza pneumonia, and hyponatremia. A lumbar puncture was performed, showing no signs of infection

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old man who is currently on day 14 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU due to altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.

The patient has several medical complications that need to be addressed:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient has quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates, which are highly suggestive of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). This is likely caused by sepsis and known parainfluenza pneumonia, given a PaO2:FiO2 ratio less than 200. Other possible causes include volume overload from renal failure, post-transplant reaction, and engraftment syndrome. The patient's BAL viral screen is positive for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen, but negative for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP).

2. Fevers: The patient has persistent fevers, which could be due to various causes such as blood clot, drug-related side effects, line infection, urinary tract infection, or sinusitis. Further evaluation is needed, including LE dopplers to look for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), CT sinuses, CMV viral load testing, and consideration of pulling lines.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely multifactorial, related

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent a bone marrow transplant for multiple myeloma and is now experiencing progressive respiratory and renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for volume removal due to persistent anuria. The patient has been tolerating pressure support ventilation (PSV) well, and his respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) has improved. However, he continues to have persistent fevers, with a temperature of 100.3 degrees Fahrenheit.

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and sepsis. He has been started on meropenem after desensitization, and his blood cultures are negative for organisms. Despite this, he has ongoing fevers without a clear source.

The plan for the patient's care includes continuing to support respiratory failure with low-dose Versed and fentanyl, while maintaining PSV and gradually decreasing PEEP. The patient will be moved to spontaneous breathing trials if tolerated. For acute renal failure, CVVH will continue for volume removal, and the renal team will discuss the possibility of moving to intermittent hemodialysis (HD) and setting up a schedule with a possible first dialysis today.

Regarding sepsis, the patient will continue to receive micafungin and meropenem. Re-imaging for sinus infection will be organized with interruption in CVVH timing, and the renal team will be

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) and is currently on day +14. He was transferred to the ICU for altered mental status, hypoxia, and desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient is intubated and sedated, with limited responsiveness. He has fever, tachycardia, and hypoxia. He is receiving heparin empirically for possible pulmonary embolism (PE), IV metoprolol, and various other medications.

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Distress: The patient has evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). The differential diagnosis includes volume overload from renal failure, post-transplant reaction, and engraftment syndrome. The patient's PaO2:FiO2 ratio is less than 200, indicating severe hypoxemia. The patient is being weaned off PEEP and undergoing daily pressure support trials. A spontaneous breathing trial is planned.
2. Fevers: The cause of the patient's fevers is uncertain. Potential causes include blood clot, drug-related effects, line infection, urinary tract infection, or sinusitis. Doppler examinations for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are recommended. Further infectious disease recommendations are needed, and a CT scan of the sinuses is advised.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who is currently on day 14 of an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU for altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization due to an ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient has multiple comorbidities including type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, GERD, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Distress: The patient is experiencing rapidly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates, suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The cause could be sepsis, known parainfluenza pneumonia, volume overload from renal failure, post-transplant reaction, or engraftment syndrome.

2. Fevers: The patient has persistent fevers, which could be attributed to various causes such as blood clots, drug-related reactions, line infections, urinary tract infections, or sinusitis. Further evaluation with LE dopplers, infectious disease recommendations, CT sinuses, and consideration of line removal may be necessary.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient has an altered mental status likely related to infection and hypercarbia due to parainfluenza pneumonia. This could be further worsened by hyponatremia. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures remain negative for additional infection.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old man with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT). He was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, which is suggestive of ARDS. He also has acute renal failure, likely multifactorial, and is undergoing continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). The patient has several other medical complications, including atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, anemia, hyponatremia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires mechanical ventilation. There is a concern for ARDS, which is associated with poor prognosis.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has oliguric renal failure, possibly due to multiple factors such as hypotension, increased lactate, volume depletion, supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, recent contrast load, and acyclovir toxicity. CVVH is being used to manage renal function.
3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response: The patient has developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which needs to be managed with antiarrhythmic medication

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent a bone marrow transplant for multiple myeloma. He is currently experiencing progressive respiratory failure and renal failure, requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) for volume removal due to persistent anuria. The patient has been tolerating pressure support ventilation (PSV) wean well and has shown favorable respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) in the morning. However, the patient's blood pressure stability has required IV medications for stabilization. He also has persistent fevers, and possible sources such as sinusitis and catheter seeding are being considered.

The patient's current medical complications include:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing acute hypoxia in the setting of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The etiology of the respiratory failure is unclear, and there is a risk of pulmonary embolism. The patient is on low-dose Versed and Fentanyl, and PSV is being continued. The patient will continue to be supported through continued volume removal, and a trial decrease in PEEP will be attempted today with a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT), but extubation is not recommended due to overnight events. The patient is also on IV heparin empirically, and a pulmonary embolism will be checked for.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is experiencing acute renal failure, and CVVH will continue for volume removal today. The renal

   61 yo man s/p alogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred to the
   [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem
   desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory failure: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   were highly suggestive of ARDS given P:F <200 in setting of sepsis and
   known parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia. Negative for PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 7453**] also
   includes volume overload from renal failure and now question of
   pulmonary embolism. Post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome
   less likely.
   -Cont to mechanically vent; unable to tolerate SBT today; retry
   tomorrow
   -Cntinue meropenem, vancomycin, and micafungin
   -Avoiding steroids given parainfluenza
   -Cont heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80
   -Improvement in respiratory status will largely depend on improved
   renal function. HD deferred in favor of CVVH given lower running BP.
   Will ultrafiltrate as BP tolerates
   # Fevers: PE (negative LENIs) versus drug-related (?meropenem despite
   desensitization) versus line infection versus sinusitis versus
   abdominal abscess
   -Appreciate ID recs
   -Continue current abx
   -CT torso
   -Continue empiric heparin gtt. Unable to do CTA given ARF. V/Q scan may
   not be informative given underlying pulm dz. Will order TTE to evaluate
   for R heart strain. [**Month (only) 51**] also be able to see evidence of RV enlargement
   on CT chest w/o contrast.
   -Check diff for eos, urine eos to r/o drug fever
   -Await cx data from pulled line. Consider pulling portacath if
   continuing to spike.
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -will leave lines in for now, pending surveillance cultures
   -CIS, f/u blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # Afib with RVR:
   [**Month/Day (2) 7453**]: Increased adrenergic surge [**12-17**] acute insult in setting of good
   substrate (known mild LA enlargement) v. PE
   -Low-running BP limits ability to use metoprolol or dilt boluses; will
   start on amiodarone gtt which may also help remain in sinus rhythm
   should cardioversion become necessary
   -PE workup as above
   -Decrease adrenergic stimuli w/ Tylenol prn for fever, cont treating
   infection, keep adequately sedated
   # ARF: Oliguric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top
   of the differential.
   -continue CVVH per renal team
   -dose all meds for GFR <10
   -continue to hold acyclovir
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.
   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret
   in the setting of neutropenia but nl glucose and total protein
   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   -CSF studies negative to date. Continue to follow up other culture
   data.
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # Anemia: Hematocrit stable
   -trend CBC
   -guiaic all stools
   -transfuse for <21
   # Myeloma: Patient is s/p of SCT for multiple myeloma.
   -Dose cyclosporine per level (50mg IV today, recheck CSA level tomorrow
   at 9pm); goal around 200.
   -f/u BMT recs
   -holding acyclovir d/t probable acyclovir-related acute renal failure
   -nystatin for thrush prophylaxis
   -continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   -continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil;
   -avoiding steroids if possible d/t viral pneumonia
   # Hyponatremia: Most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia. Currently stable.
   -continue to monitor daily sodium
   -continue free water restriction
   -CVVH as above
   # Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Difficult to control blood glucose in the
   setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   -appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   -continue humalog sliding scale with Lantus, followed FSG and adjust
   per tube feed status
   # Hypertension: Patient has a history of hypertension in the past
   requiring metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 **] and amlodipine 2.5 qday. Here had required
   addition of nitro gtt but currently more hypotensive.
   -Hold metoprolol and amlodipine
   -Amiodarone for afib
   -CVVH as above; will avoid large fluid shifts
   -[**Month (only) 51**] need to start pressors if unable to maintain MAP>65
   # Depression: Patient has a history of major depression with
   significant medication requirements.
   -appreciate psychiatry input
   -holding duloxetine for now
   # Glaucoma
   -continue timolol eye drops
   # Hyperlipidemia

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma and was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.

The patient has several medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates consistent with ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) due to parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia. There is also a concern for pulmonary embolism (PE) and volume overload from renal failure.

2. Fevers: The cause of the fevers is uncertain, with possible causes including PE, drug-related reactions (meropenem despite desensitization), line infection, sinusitis, or abdominal abscess. No peripheral or urinary eosinophils are present, making sinusitis less likely. Current antibiotics are being continued, and a CT torso is planned.

3. E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: The patient had a previous UTI caused by ESBL E. coli, which was successfully treated with aztreonam. However, recent cultures have shown ESBL bacteremia. The patient has undergone successful desensitization to meropenem and is now on this antibiotic. Surveillance cultures are pending, and meropenem will be continued.

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male who has undergone a bone marrow transplant for multiple myeloma. He is currently experiencing multiple medical complications including acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, sepsis/hypotension, and multiple myeloma.

1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute hypoxia in the setting of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The etiology of the respiratory failure is unclear, but there is a concern for possible pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient is being supported with continued volume removal through CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis) and plans to wean off PSV (partial liquid ventilation). Sedation will be decreased further with Versed/Fentanyl, and a trial decrease in PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) to 5 for spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) will be done.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is experiencing acute renal failure, and CVVH will continue for volume removal today. The renal team is considering moving to intermittent hemodialysis going forward.

3. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient had an episode of bacteremia caused by ESBL (extended-spectrum beta-lactamase) E. coli and was treated with Meropenem after desensitization. Blood cultures are currently negative for organisms. The patient has ongoing low-grade fevers without

   -continue to monitor daily sodium

   -appreciate psychiatry input

   -continue timolol eye drops
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -holding atorvastatin in acute setting

The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. He has a history of multiple myeloma and underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant. The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and has been diagnosed with several medical complications including atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, acute renal failure, anemia, hyponatremia, ileus, type 2 diabetes mellitus, labile blood pressure, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy and pain, GERD, and others.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure due to ARDS and requires mechanical ventilation. Continued support and monitoring are necessary to improve respiratory status.

2. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has signs suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, including increased tachycardia, acute desaturation, and right ventricular dilation. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to confirm and manage this condition.

3. Infection: The patient has recurrent fevers, which could indicate ongoing infection. Cultures have been obtained, but results are pending. Empiric antibiotic therapy has been initiated, and the source of infection needs to be identified and treated accordingly.

4. Acute Renal

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent a bone marrow transplant (BMT) for multiple myeloma. He is currently experiencing progressive respiratory failure and renal failure. He has been placed on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for volume removal due to persistent anuria. The patient's blood pressure has stabilized, and he has shown good tolerance to partial liquid ventilation (PLV) wean. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk of pulmonary embolism (PE), and there is uncertainty about the underlying cause of his acute hypoxia. Further evaluation is needed to determine the etiology and appropriate treatment.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has deteriorated, leading to acute renal failure. CVVH will continue to support volume removal, and the renal team is considering a transition to intermittent hemodialysis (HD).
3. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient has been treated for ESBL E. coli bacteremia and started on meropenem after desensitization. Despite this, he continues to have low-grade fevers without a clear etiology. It is important to monitor for signs of infection and consider potential sources, such as drug fever or occult infection.
4. Multiple Myeloma: The patient's multiple myeloma requires ongoing management and support in the post-BMT setting.

He was admitted to the ICU for severe ARDS and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's current vital signs include a heart rate of 124 bpm, blood pressure of 131/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on FiO2 40%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows an arterial line inserted on [**2165-3-18**] and a dialysis catheter inserted on [**2165-3-21**]. The patient has been receiving various medications including amiodarone, heparin sodium, midazolam, fentanyl, metoprolol, and nitroglycerin. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, which increases the risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Prolonged immobilization in the ICU can increase the risk of developing DVT, especially in patients with malignancy.
3. Stress ulcers: The patient's critical illness and prolonged ICU stay may increase the risk of stress ulcers, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent a bone marrow transplant. He has developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure (ARF), atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (afib with RVR), and is currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) for volume removal. The patient also has sepsis/hypotension with ongoing low-grade fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, and is suspected to have an esbl e coli bacteremia. Additionally, the patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and chronic kidney disease.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is complicated by ARDS, which is characterized by severe inflammation and fluid accumulation in the lungs. This can lead to progressive hypoxia and respiratory distress.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely secondary to sepsis and ARDS. This can result in impaired kidney function and the need for ongoing renal replacement therapy, such as CVVH.

3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (afib with RVR): The patient's heart rhythm is currently in atrial fibrillation with RVR. This condition increases the risk of stroke and heart failure. Efforts are being made to control the heart rate, but it remains unstable.

4. Sepsis/Hyp

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent a bone marrow transplant (BMT). He is currently experiencing progressive respiratory failure and acute renal failure. He is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for volume removal due to anuria. The patient has had good tolerance of pressure support ventilation (PSV) wean and improved blood pressure stability. He has been experiencing low-grade fevers, which could be attributed to typical ICU infections such as sinusitis or catheter seeding. His respiratory failure appears to be multifactorial, with worsening acute hypoxia in the setting of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib/RVR), possible pulmonary embolism (PE), parainfluenza infection, and treating for extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) bacteremia. The patient is also experiencing acute renal failure and sepsis/hypotension, with ongoing low-grade fevers despite being on appropriate antibiotics. Other medical conditions include hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and multiple myeloma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure/ARDS/volume overload: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and may be caused by worsening acute hypoxia, possible PE, parainfluenza infection, and ESBL bacteremia. There is a concern for volume overload as well.

2. Acute Renal

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent a bone marrow transplant for multiple myeloma and subsequently developed respiratory failure, ARDS, and acute renal failure. He has been on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) for volume removal. The patient's condition is further complicated by persistent low-grade fevers, the development of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF with RVR), and potential pulmonary embolism (PE). 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is complicated by volume overload and acute hypoxia in the setting of AF with RVR. This may require further attempts at fluid removal with CVVH and optimization for future weaning.

2. ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to parainfluenza pneumonia and presumed PE. Management includes continued ventilator support, broad antibacterial and antifungal treatments, and careful fluid management.

3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has ARF and is currently on CVVH for volume removal. Transition to hemodialysis (HD) may be limited due to AF and RVR. Continued CVVH is planned.

4. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient had ESBL E. coli bacteremia and is now on meropenem after desensitization. Despite broad-spectrum antibiotics, the patient continues to have low-grade fevers.

The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, renal failure, and multiple myeloma. He was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient also has parainfluenza pneumonia and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has ARDS and known parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia. There is concern for pulmonary embolism due to increased tachycardia, acute desaturation, and new RV dilation.
2. Sepsis/ E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: The patient has a history of ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] and subsequent clearance after aztreonam treatment. He is now on meropenem per ID recommendations.
3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (RVR): The patient's adrenergic surge has led to an increased heart rate in the 120-130s. Amiodarone was initially started but discontinued on [**3-25**] as it had little effect. Lopressor was switched to IV due to concerns for absorption.
4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient likely has oliguric

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man who has been admitted to the ICU with multiple medical complications. Here are the potential medical complications that can arise from the information given:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has bilateral patchy infiltrates consistent with ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), which can lead to respiratory failure. This is due to sepsis and known parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia.

2. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient has an increased tachycardia, acute desaturation, and new RV (right ventricular) dilation, which raises concerns for a pulmonary embolism. The TTE (transesophageal echocardiogram) also shows R heart strain suggestive of PE.

3. Renal Failure: The patient is experiencing oliguric renal failure, likely multifactorial in origin. Factors contributing to renal failure include hypotension in the setting of intubation, increased lactate, volume depletion, supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin, recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Acyclovir-related ARF (acute renal failure) is at the top of the differential.

4. Infection: The patient has recurrent fevers, making it difficult to determine the source of infection. Possible sources include PE, drug-related reactions (meropenem despite desensitization), line infection, sinus

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, renal failure, multiple myeloma, and acute respiratory distress syndrome. He is currently admitted to the ICU for further management.

Based on the progress note, the patient has experienced several events over the past 24 hours. The trans-thoracic echo revealed right ventricular dilatation and hypokinesis, raising concern for a pulmonary embolism. As a result, the patient underwent right port removal and placement of a left subclavian line. Heparin infusion was temporarily stopped for 6 hours pre- and post-procedure.

The patient is currently receiving multiple medications including midazolam, fentanyl, heparin, metoprolol, and others. His allergies include penicillins, morphine, and Dilaudid-HP. The last doses of antibiotics administered were vancomycin on 03/24/2165, micafungin on 03/25/2165, and meropenem on 03/25/2165.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.7°C (98.1°F), current temperature 35.7°C (96.2°F), heart rate 107 bpm with atrial fibrillation, blood pressure 116/58 mmHg, respiratory rate 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 99%. The patient's weight is currently 133.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent a bone marrow transplant. He developed an esbl e coli bacteremia, which led to progressive respiratory failure/ards in the setting of parainfluenza pneumonia and presumed pulmonary embolism. The patient also has acute renal failure, for which he is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for volume removal.

The patient's course has been further complicated by persistent low-grade fevers, development of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and anasarca. The patient is currently on broad antibacterial and antifungal treatments.

The patient's current problems include acute respiratory failure, ARDS, parainfluenza pneumonia, presumed pulmonary embolism, acute renal failure, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, multiple myeloma, and ileus.

The plan includes continuing broad antibacterial and antifungal treatments, moving towards pressure support weans, attempting fluid removal with CVVH as the blood pressure allows, optimizing for future wean, continuing IV heparin empirically, transitioning to hemodialysis in the near future, pursuing a tunnel line, and addressing other ongoing issues.

The patient's condition is described as critically ill.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent bone marrow transplantation (BMT). He presented with sepsis due to an extended spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) Escherichia coli bacteremia. The patient developed progressive respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in the setting of parainfluenza pneumonia (PNA) and presumed pulmonary embolism (PE). He also has acute renal failure (ARF) on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for volume removal.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is slowly improving. Continue broad antibiotic and antifungal treatment. Move towards pressure support weans on the ventilator. Attempt fluid removal with CVVH as blood pressure allows to better optimize for future wean. Continue intravenous heparin for presumed PE.
2. ARF: Continue CVVH for volume removal. Renal function will likely transition to hemodialysis (HD) in the near future. Pursue tunnel line placement for prolonged dialysis needs.
3. Sepsis: Continued low-grade fevers without additional etiology identified despite broad coverage. Now with temperatures masked by CVVH. Consider drug fever vs occult ICU infection such as sinusitis vs possible seeding of catheters. All old lines and port are now out. Continue Micafungin

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with multiple medical conditions including hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, renal failure, multiple myeloma, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate 119 bpm (with fluctuations between 108-131 bpm), blood pressure 123/72 mmHg (with fluctuations), respiratory rate 23 breaths per minute (with fluctuations), and oxygen saturation at 100%. 

The patient has been receiving various medications including lopressor, metoprolol, midazolam, fentanyl, and morphine. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, elevated blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, and lactate levels. The patient's electrolytes are within normal range. 

Imaging and microbiology tests are pending. 

The patient has been on dialysis and has had multiple lines inserted, including an arterial line, dialysis catheter, midline, and multi-lumen line. 

The patient's nutrition and glycemic control are being monitored, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia is being administered. 

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is still pending.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old man who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma. He was admitted to the ICU due to altered mental status, hypoxia, and the need for meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient also had parainfluenza pneumonia and new-onset atrial fibrillation, raising concerns for pulmonary embolism. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been experiencing respiratory failure due to ARDS and known parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia. There is also a concern for volume overload from renal failure and possible pulmonary embolism. 

Medical Complications:
1. Atrial Fibrillation (AFIB): The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently experiencing AFIB with rapid ventricular response. Treatment includes low-dose diltiazem and amiodarone, but the patient's heart rate remains elevated.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory status has been improving but recently failed a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and pressure support ventilation (PSV) due to oversedation or myopathy. Sedation is being reduced prior to a second trial of PSV.
3. Sepsis/ESBL E. coli Bacteremia: The patient had a previous UTI caused by ESBL E. coli, which was cleared with aztreonam. He is currently on meropenem, vancomycin, and micafungin for at least a two-week course due to persistent bacteremia.
4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has oliguric renal failure, likely multifactorial in origin. Acyclovir-related ARF is suspected due to numerous crystals in the urine sediment. Continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) is being continued, and medications are being adjusted for a GFR of approximately 30.
5. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is stable, and improvement is likely due to CVVH fluid shifts. Blood transfusions are being considered for a hematocrit below 21.
6. Myeloma: The patient underwent stem cell transplantation for multiple myeloma. Medications such as cyclosporine and mycophenolate mofetil are being administered per BMT recommendations.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is improving and is likely related to SIADH secondary to pain and/or pneumonia.
8. Ileus: The patient has high residuals and poor nutritional status, making tube feeding difficult. Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) has been started.
9. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's blood glucose control is challenging due to infection, underlying diabetes, and steroids.
10. Depression: The patient has a history of major depression and requires medication, but duloxetine is being withheld

4. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may require transition to hemodialysis soon. Close monitoring of renal function and fluid balance is necessary.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's AFib is not well-controlled, making rate control a concern. Close monitoring of heart rhythm and adjusting medication dosages as needed is important.

The patient's condition has rapidly deteriorated, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure, and sepsis. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation in the ICU. He requires continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) for volume removal and is expected to transition to hemodialysis in the near future. The patient's nutrition is poor, and he is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). He also has an ileus and is unable to take oral medications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration or complications related to mechanical ventilation.
2. ARDS: The patient has ARDS, which can lead to progressive lung injury and respiratory failure. Complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) may occur.
3. Parainfluenza Pneumonia (PNA): The patient is suspected to have parainfluenza pneumonia, which can worsen his respiratory function and overall condition.
4. Presumed Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient is at high risk for pulmonary embolism due to immobilization, multiple comorbidities, and

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU for altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient also has parainfluenza pneumonia, new-onset atrial fibrillation (AFIB), and concerns for pulmonary embolism (PE).

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure due to ARDS and parainfluenza pneumonia, sepsis/E. coli bacteremia and urinary tract infection (UTI), AFIB with right ventricular strain suggesting PE, acute renal failure (ARF), anemia, myeloma, hyponatremia, ileus, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and glaucoma.

The patient is receiving various treatments including CVVH (continuous venovenous hemofiltration), meropenem, vancomycin, micafungin, metoprolol, heparin gtt (continuous infusion), TPN (total parenteral nutrition), regular insulin sliding scale, and prophylactic medications such as DVT prophylaxis, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this case include worsening respiratory failure, sepsis/bacteremia, PE, ARF,

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He was transferred to the ICU due to altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient also has parainfluenza pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, concern for pulmonary embolism (PE), and continued volume overload requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has complex respiratory failure due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia, possible altered mental status, possible PE, and continued volume overload. The plan is to continue hepatic flow, switch sedation from fentanyl/midazolam to propofol for controlled weaning, and continue CVVH.

2. Sepsis/E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: The patient has ongoing sepsis and E. coli bacteremia with a urinary tract infection (UTI). He is currently on meropenem after desensitization. His hemodynamics vary widely due to agitation, atrial fibrillation, and underlying infection. The plan is to continue meropenem, vancomycin, and micafungin for at least a two-week course until April 1st. Blood and line cultures will be followed, and ID

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He is currently in the ICU due to multiple complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis with E. coli bacteremia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, acute renal failure, anemia, myeloma, ileus, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F), heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 163/72 mmHg to 186/101 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and irregular atrial fibrillation. The patient is intubated and sedated, with grimacing to pain. Physical examination reveals mild coarse breath sounds, 1+ pitting edema on the dorsum of feet, and upper extremities bilaterally edematous but non-pitting. The patient has a right-sided atrial line in place.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 207,000/uL, elevated hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 34 mg/dL, elevated creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL, and elevated lactate level of 0.

The patient is a 72-year-old male with multiple medical problems, including hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, renal failure, multiple myeloma, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's current condition involves acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), requiring mechanical ventilation in the ICU. 

The patient's vital signs show a blood pressure of 163/72 mmHg with fluctuating readings ranging from 71-186 mmHg systolic, a heart rate of 98 bpm, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and temperature within normal range. 

The patient has a history of altered nutrition and has been receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) with lipids since March 28th. 

Laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count of 10.9 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, elevated blood glucose levels ranging from 123-176 mg/dL, and abnormal renal function tests with a creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL. 

The patient has multiple lines and catheters in place, including an arterial line, dialysis catheter, midline catheter, and multi-lumen catheter. Prophylactic measures include systemic anticoagulation for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer prophylaxis with proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prevention strategies such as head of bed

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

The patient has been experiencing volatile blood pressures, ranging from the 70s to 170s systolic, which has made it difficult to establish a hemodynamic line. CSA 25mg IV was administered, and the patient's sedation was switched from fentanyl/midazolam to propofol to allow for more controlled weaning and assessment of mental status.

The patient also has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and is being treated with metoprolol. He has oliguric renal failure, possibly due to sepsis/hypotension and acyclovir-related complications. CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis) is ongoing, and the patient is scheduled for a hemodialysis (HD) line placement today.

The patient's anemia is improving, likely due to CVVH fluid shifts. His myeloma status post SCT requires ongoing management with cyclosporine and mycophenolate mofetil. The patient also has an ileus, which is being managed with total parenteral nutrition (TPN).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure due to ARDS, parainfluenza type

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma on [**2165-3-8**]. He has multiple medical complications including atrial fibrillation, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), sepsis with E. coli bacteremia, acute renal failure, and diabetes mellitus type II.

The patient's respiratory failure is complex and has various etiologies such as ARDS, parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia, possible altered mental status, and possible pulmonary embolism (PE). He is currently on mechanical ventilation and sedated with propofol. The patient's oxygenation has improved with volume removal.

The patient also has sepsis and E. coli bacteremia, for which he is being treated with meropenem. Additionally, he is on vancomycin and micafungin for fungal infection.

The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is being controlled with metoprolol IV, and amiodarone can be used if he cannot tolerate metoprolol.

Acute renal failure is present, which is multifactorial, including sepsis/hypotension and acyclovir-related. CVVH is being held pending renal recommendations. Acyclovir is being held, and valgancyclovir is being started per ID.

Anemia is indicated by a hematocrit drop overnight

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure with a complex etiology including ARDS, parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia, possible PE, volume overload/anasarca, sepsis/E. coli bacteremia and UTI, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, acute renal failure, anemia, and multiple myeloma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has ARDS and possible PE, which can lead to respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring of oxygen saturation, ventilation, and respiratory effort is necessary. If necessary, the patient may require intubation and mechanical ventilation.

2. Sepsis/E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: The patient is currently being treated with meropenem for E. coli bacteremia and UTI. Monitoring of vital signs, blood cultures, and urine output is essential. If the patient's condition worsens, additional antibiotics may be required.

3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (RVR): The patient is receiving metoprolol to control his heart rate. Continuous monitoring of the heart rate and rhythm is necessary. If the patient is unable to tolerate metoprolol, amiodarone can be considered.

4. Acute Renal Failure

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma with respiratory failure (ARDS, Paraflu, possible PE), E. coli bacteremia, and mental status changes. The patient has several medical complications that need attention.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has complex etiology including ARDS, parainfluenza type 3 pneumonia, possible PE, and volume overload. The main impediment to extubation is the volume overload. The plan includes restarting heparin gtt at previous rate without bolus, continuing pressure support ventilation, removing volume as tolerated, and attempting extubation in the upcoming 1-2 days.

2. Sepsis/E. coli bacteremia and UTI: The patient is currently on meropenem after desensitization. WBC count is stable, but cannot trust absence of fevers given CVVH. The plan includes continuing meropenem, vancomycin, and micafungin for at least a two-week course until 4/1.

3. Atrial Fibrillation (AFIB): The patient has persistent elevated heart rate despite being on metoprolol and digoxin. Possible contributions from intravascular volume depletion as well as pain/anxiety are considered. The plan includes continuing metoprolol at the current dose, increasing digoxin to 0.125 mg

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension, benign; diabetes mellitus type II; renal failure, acute; multiple myeloma (cancer, malignant neoplasm); and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS, acute lung injury). The patient remains intubated and on mechanical ventilation in the ICU. He continues to have significant fluid requirements due to ongoing losses. Propofol infusion has been increased for sedation. Vancomycin will be discontinued tomorrow, and heparin will be restarted. Digoxin dose has been increased, which has improved right ventricular function.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 90/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a regular rhythm. Weight is 129.8 kg.

Fluid balance shows a total input of 10,678 mL and total output of 18,588 mL, resulting in a deficit of -7,910 mL.
